DataElement.preferredDefinition: the name of the laboratory test that was peformed.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a laboratory test that was performed.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the name of the laboratory procedure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The real number of white blood cells (WBC) that are neutrophils. It is derived by multiplying the WBC count by the percent of neutrophils in the differential WBC count. The normal range for ANC is 1.5 to 8.0 (1,500 to 8,000/mm3).

Concepts.definition: The real number of white blood cells (WBC) that are neutrophils. It is derived by multiplying the WBC count by the percent of neutrophils in the differential WBC count. The normal range for ANC is 1.5 to 8.0 (1,500 to 8,000/mm3).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of hemoglobin present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of hemoglobin present in a biospecimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measure of the volume of red blood cells expressed as a percentage of the total blood volume. Normal in males is 43-49%, in females 37-43%.

Concepts.definition: A measure of the volume of red blood cells expressed as a percentage of the total blood volume. Normal in males is 43-49%, in females 37-43%.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A test to determine the number of leukocytes in a sample of blood.

Concepts.definition: A test to determine the number of leukocytes in a biospecimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the number of platelets in a blood sample, usually expressed as platelets per cubic millimeter (cmm) of whole blood.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the number of platelets in a biospecimen.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of magnesium present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of magnesium present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the calcium in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of calcium present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sodium
A measurement of the potassium in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of potassium present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the chloride in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of chloride present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Glucose Plasma Concentration (GPC) measurement is an essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements including diabetes mellitus. The disordered carbohydrate metabolism that underlies diabetes manifests as hyperglycemia. Plasma glucose concentrations in healthy individuals vary with age. Normal fasting plasma glucose intervals (in the morning after an overnight fast) in children are 3.3 - 5.6 mmol/L (60-100 mg/dL); adult range - 4.1- 5.9 mmol/L (74-106 mg/dL). GPCs are approximately 11% higher than whole blood if the hematocrit is normal. Glucose concentrations in heparinized plasma are reported to be 5% lower than in serum.

Concepts.definition: Glucose Plasma Concentration (GPC) measurement is an essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements including diabetes mellitus. The disordered carbohydrate metabolism that underlies diabetes manifests as hyperglycemia. Plasma glucose concentrations in healthy individuals vary with age. Normal fasting plasma glucose intervals (in the morning after an overnight fast) in children are 3.3 - 5.6 mmol/L (60-100 mg/dL); adult range - 4.1- 5.9 mmol/L (74-106 mg/dL). GPCs are approximately 11% higher than whole blood if the hematocrit is normal. Glucose concentrations in heparinized plasma are reported to be 5% lower than in serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the uric acid crystals present in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the amount of uric acid crystals present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.: A quantitative measurement of the amount of creatinine present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of creatinine present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of urea nitrogen present in a serum sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of urea nitrogen present in a serum sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the clotting time of plasma recalcified in the presence of excess tissue thromboplastin; it is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. It is used to determine the clotting tendency of blood, in the measure of warfarin dosage, liver damage and vitamin K status. Factors measured are fibrinogen, prothrombin, and factors V, VII, and X.

Concepts.definition: A measurement of the clotting time of plasma recalcified in the presence of excess tissue thromboplastin; it is a measure of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. It is used to determine the clotting tendency of blood, in the measure of warfarin dosage, liver damage and vitamin K status. Factors measured are fibrinogen, prothrombin, and factors V, VII, and X.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: System established by the World Health Organization and the International Committee on Thrombosis and Hemostasis for monitoring and reporting blood coagulation tests. Under this system, results are standardized using the International Sensitivity Index for the particular test reagent/instrument combination used.

Concepts.definition: A system, commonly called the INR, established by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the International Committee on Thrombosis and Hemostasis for reporting the results of blood coagulation (clotting) tests. All results are standardized using the international sensitivity index (ISI) for the particular thromboplastin reagent and instrument combination utilized to perform the test; the ratio of a patient's clotting time to the lab's mean reference value is normalized against the ISI. (from medterms.com and medicine.ucsf.edu)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Test of the intrinsic (factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII) and common (fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V and X) pathways of coagulation in which a mixture of plasma and phospholipid platelet substitute (e.g., crude cephalins, soybean phosphatides) is recalcified and the time required for the appearance of fibrin strands measured. Activation may be provided by contact with the glass tube or exposure to activators (e.g., ellagic acid, particulate silicates such as diatomaceous earth or kaolin) before addition of the calcium chloride. It is used as a screening test and to monitor heparin therapy.

Concepts.definition: Test of the intrinsic (factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII) and common (fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V and X) pathways of coagulation in which a mixture of plasma and phospholipid platelet substitute (e.g., crude cephalins, soybean phosphatides) is recalcified and the time required for the appearance of fibrin strands measured. Activation may be provided by contact with the glass tube or exposure to activators (e.g., ellagic acid, particulate silicates such as diatomaceous earth or kaolin) before addition of the calcium chloride. It is used as a screening test and to monitor heparin therapy.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the fibrinogen in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of fibrinogen present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of human chorionic gonadotropin present in a sample of serum.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of human chorionic gonadotropin present in a sample of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.: A sialoglycoprotein hormone secreted by the placenta and maintains the corpus luteum at the beginning of the gestation period.(NCI)

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra.
A sialoglycoprotein hormone secreted by the placenta and maintains the corpus luteum at the beginning of the gestation period.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The major hormone derived from the thyroid gland. Thyroxine is synthesized via the iodination of tyrosines (MONOIODOTYROSINE) and the coupling of iodotyrosines (DIIODOTYROSINE) in the THYROGLOBULIN. Thyroxine is released from thyroglobulin by proteolysis and secreted into the blood. Thyroxine is peripherally deiodinated to form TRIIODOTHYRONINE which exerts a broad spectrum of stimulatory effects on cell metabolism.

Concepts.definition: A hormone synthesized and secreted by the thyroid gland containing four iodine atoms and is converted to triiodothyronine (T3) in the body, influencing metabolism and organ function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A hormone produced by the pituitary gland. TSH stimulates the release of thyroid hormone from thyroglobulin. It also stimulates the growth of thyroid follicular cells. An abnormal TSH level may mean that the thyroid hormonal regulation system is out of control, usually as a result of a benign condition (hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism).: A measurement of the thyrotropin in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A peptide hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary. It promotes the growth of the thyroid gland and stimulates the synthesis of thyroid hormones and the release of thyroxine by the thyroid gland.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of thyrotropin present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Bilirubin is a breakdown product of hemoglobin. Total and direct bilirubin are usually measured to screen for or to monitor liver or gall bladder dysfunction. (from MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia)

Concepts.definition: The measurement of the total amount of bilirubin present in a particular substrate. The substrate most often tested is blood, but other fluids extracted from the body may be used periodically depending on the purpose of the test.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of aspartate aminotransferase present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of aspartate aminotransferase present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of alanine aminotransferase present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of alanine aminotransferase present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of alkaline phosphatase present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of alkaline phosphatase present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of albumin present in a sample.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of albumin present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of a group of complex organic macromolecules composed of one or more alpha-L-amino acid chains in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of total protein present in a sample.

PermissibleValues.value: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction by MUGA

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A multi-gated acquisition (MUGA) scan and a form of radionuclide imaging that provides a comprehensive look at blood flow and the function of the lower chambers of the heart ventricles.: The ejection fraction (or, more correctly, left-ventricular ejection fraction, often abbreviated LVEF) is a measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber. (Wikipedia)

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic test used to evaluate the pumping function of the heart's ventricles. A radioactive tracer is injected into a vein and a gamma camera detects the radiation released by the tracer, with image acquisition triggered (gated) at different points of the cardiac cycle.

Concepts.longName: Measurement of Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction
Concepts.definition: A measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber.

PermissibleValues.value: Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction by echocardiogram

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.: The ejection fraction (or, more correctly, left-ventricular ejection fraction, often abbreviated LVEF) is a measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber. (Wikipedia)

Concepts.definition: An image of the heart produced by ultrasonography.

Concepts.longName: Measurement of Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction
Concepts.definition: A measure of how much blood the left ventricle of the heart pumps out with each contraction. With each beat, a normal heart ejects about one-half to two-thirds of the blood in its left chamber.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the total amount of bilirubin present in a sample of serum.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the total amount of bilirubin present in a sample of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of aspartate aminotransferase present in a sample of serum.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of aspartate aminotransferase present in a sample of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of alanine aminotransferase present in a sample of serum.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of alanine aminotransferase present in a sample of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of alkaline phosphatase present in a sample of serum.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of alkaline phosphatase present in a sample of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.: An immature blood cell.

Concepts.definition: On or near an edge or constituting an outer boundary; the outer area.
A precursor cell which gives rise to a fully differentiated cell of hematopoietic lineage.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

DataElement.origin: CALGB CRF:Cancer and Leukemia Group B Case Report Form
